Author: Zeta411North

Comment: The two biggest things they needed are happening: Thom Tillis looks incredibly vulnerable in a primary and Brian Kemp is sitting it out.  That’s the (second) easiest pickup and hardest seat to defend with circumstances both trending their way.    Bigger picture, the path to the Senate goes through Maine, North Carolina, and two of Ohio, Florida, Texas, and Iowa.  It’s daunting (Trump won all four of those by at least ten points), but you can find helpful extant circumstances in all four.   Husted is running as an appointed Senator in a special election, ditto Moody (with the added bonus of a brewing public corruption scandal involving Ron DeSantis).  John Cornyn is going through an absolutely nasty primary with Ken Paxton, which he might very well lose, and Iowa is going to be disproportionally affected if the trade war goes on much longer.
Author: ScotTheDuck

Comment: Also think that WV might not be a lost cause.  It’s only recently gone Deep Red.  Before Justice, Manchin was a Democrat (at least in name) and Justice used to be a Democrat.  They’re very vulnerable to economic downturns and the abolishment of the mine safety organizations will potentially backfire. There is no love lost for billionaires and oligarchs by the mountain folks.    Antidotally, take a look at Sen Moore’s social media and 97% of the comments are very negative about her choices and performance.  They’re calling her out on her hypocrisy and policies that hurt her constituents. There will be a huge backlash if Medicare/Medicaid and other social services are cut.  That state survives on social welfare and benefits.
Author: Competitive_Ad291

Comment: Their best bet for a state to target that isn’t Maine/North Carolina is Ohio imo.   I am biased because I’m from Ohio. But polls suggest that out of all the red states to flip, Ohio is the most vulnerable, especially if Sherrod Brown runs again. He performed 7 points better than Harris in the state.  It’s still going to be an uphill battle. It’s still improbable but not impossible.

Author: StrangerFew2424

Comment: I've looked at the map it's probably impossible to regain the senate. Susan Collins in Maine and Thom Tillis in North Carolina are realistic targets. There's probably a lot of stretch targets if there is a recession e.g Dan Sullivan in Alaska, the Ohio seat in 2026, John Cornyn in Texas but I am fairly skeptical that those states are the one's most vulnerable to anti-trump backlash. I could see Texas in play if Cornyn retires and MAGA elects somewhat more viscerally antagonistic but I don't think 2026 is the year Texas flips. Steve Daines in Montana I don't think is polarizing enough to lose in a red state.   On the other hand  Osoff in Georgia could realistically lose. Without a recession or a bad Republican candidate I think this maybe even more likely than not. You also have three states (Michigan, Minnesota, New Hampshire) which while all probably going blue could conceivably be lost if the Republicans pick the right candidate. I would probably bet on them all going blue though.   So in total I see the most realistic option is a pickup of 1 seat with 2-3 seat pickup if the economy goes real south but that won't be enough to flip congress nor do I think a non-majority better margin matters much because the only realistic way to get there is to boot out Collins and McConnell's retiring which means that there will still be a voting majority of do whatever Trump wants in the senate.

Comment: Dems need to learn to win in red-ish states again, and that means capitulating to Trump on some issues, particularly immigration and trade, but promoting their own type of economic populism. The ultimate strategy, I think, is to be firmly against illegal immigration, in favor of moderate tariffs and protectionism, attack the rich and powerful more as causes for economic grievances, and support deep new economic changes like universal healthcare and/or massive new spending on housing. They need to take the current, anti-globalism mood and shift it into a productive or even progressive direction.
